main_title: Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual
title: Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual
content:
# Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual  
![Headshot of article author Jacinda Eng](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a3c2908b415eaa15df72e236d3732e1bc09dad04ed32216be500c30258a06d96?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Jacinda Eng](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/jacindaeng/ "Posts by Jacinda Eng")**
Product Manager  
October 29, 2025  
The new Card visual in Power BI will soon be generally available! This release brings a modern, visually engaging way to highlight key metrics in your reports, packed with new capabilities and significant improvements.

main_title: Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual
title: **Rendering improvements**
content:
## **Rendering improvements**  
Rendering has been completely re-engineered to align with best practices for responsive design. This means when you resize the Card visual the proportions of each section are maintained, and the bottom sections will no longer be cut off.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/old-card-rendering-v3.gif) ![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/new-card-rendering-2.gif)

main_title: Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual
title: **What this means for your existing reports**
content:
## **What this means for your existing reports**  
This rendering improvement may change how the new card visual appears in existing reports, especially for cards with short heights.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/image-8.png)  
Once released in GA, the default **callout size** and **background** formatting will be applied to the visual whether or not a divider is enabled. In public preview, these settings are only accessible when a **divider** is toggled on. Follow these steps to set the callout size and background to prepare for GA.  
1. Toggle on the **divider****.**
2. Adjust the **callout size** to your preferred look.
3. Adjust the **background** color of your reference labels to your preferred look. If you prefer to keep the background hidden when the **divider** is off, simply turn the **background** setting off to maintain your current design.
4. Keep the **divider** toggled on in the **divider** group to ensure consistent alignment and for best design practices. You can also turn off the **divider** and keep the **background** and **callout size** settings applied on the visual.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Screenshot-2025-10-24-153826-1024x816.png)  
As we make changes, learn more about the new card visual at [Create a (new) card visual in Power BI](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/visuals/power-bi-visualization-new-card).

main_title: Preparing for the General Availability of the new Card visual
title: **What else is new as part of GA?**
content:
## **What else is new as part of GA?**  
* **Enhanced image support**: Highlight key images to your cards for a richer storytelling experience.  
* **Collage layout**: Organize metrics and sections in a clean, collage format.  
* **Expanded styling controls**: Enjoy a broader range of customization options including section-specific backgrounds, rounded corner styling for multi-category tiles, and more!  
![A comparison of a beach and a mountain AI-generated content may be incorrect.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/a-comparison-of-a-beach-and-a-mountain-ai-generat.png)  
* **Updated defaults** **(opt-in for existing report)**: Delivers a cleaner, modern layout with improved spacing and typography, making your visuals easier to read and more professional by default.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/image-6.png)  
To use the new defaults, update your base Power BI theme for your report via the theme dialog.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/image-2-1.png)  
With these updates, the new Card visual gives you more flexibility and modern styling, making it easier than ever to create polished, impactful reports in Power BI.

main_title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
content:
# Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)  
![Headshot of article author Dustin Askins](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/be68de61a6fb04bd621d51b5a1ea6710294cd21bdf219a34d9e42eb8a85f1a5a?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Dustin Askins](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/duaskins/ "Posts by Dustin Askins")**
Product Manager, Power BI  
October 28, 2025  
Decisions happen in context. And apps are curated and customized content experiences for reporting around a context like an app for a project, an app for a department, or an app for leadership reporting. So, we’re excited to announce that the ability to chat with your curated data (like [standalone Copilot](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/copilot-chat-with-data-standalone)) within the context of an app!  
![Screenshot of app Copilot with new badge with standalone Copilot and report Copilot alongside.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/standalone-copilot-app-copilot-new-report-copilot-1024x305.png)  
App-scoped Copilot lets users search for reports within an app, ask questions, and receive answers based on the reports in that app. App Copilot is a separate complement to report-scoped Copilot already available on each report viewed in an app.  
![Screenshot showing app-scoped Copilot next to a screenshot showing report-scoped Copilot in an app](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/app-copilot-and-report-copilot-1024x331.png)  
App-scoped Copilot (Preview) and report-scoped Copilot, both available in apps.

main_title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
title: Ask questions or get summaries
content:
## Ask questions or get summaries  
Use app Copilot to ask questions or get summaries based on reports in the app. Find app Copilot in your app navigation and ask a question. Looking over the curated content in your app, Copilot will first find the most likely items you’d want to reference, ask you to confirm which one you’d like to use, and then return the result.  
![Screenshot of a question in app-scoped Copilot with an answer returned based on a selected item](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/app-copilot-question-pick-item-answer-1-1024x845.png)  
With [verified answers](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/copilot-prepare-data-ai-verified-answers), app authors can work with report authors to prepare your data for AI and trigger human-approved, visual responses that get matched with predefined phrases.  
![Screenshot of a question in app-scoped Copilot with a verified answer returned based on a selected item](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/app-copilot-va-item-va-returned-1024x800.png)  
***Helpful tips for app authors:*** make sure your app users get connected with those human-approved answers, update your app after verified answers have been created to push all report changes into your app.  
Just like in standalone Coplot, ask for summaries to get insights and visuals based on an entire report or a specific topic with that report. For example, if you know exactly which report you’d like to summarize, you can attach it to your chat using *‘+’ Add content for Copilot to reference*…then ask for your summary:  
![Screenshot of attaching an item in app-scoped Copilot and asking for a summary based on that attached item](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/app-copilot-attach-item-summary-response-1024x1008.png)

main_title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
title: Find reporting based on your interests
content:
## Find reporting based on your interests  
New to an app or looking to find reporting based on a specific interest? Get to insights faster with Copilot helping you find just the right report an app:  
![Screenshot of a search from within app-scoped Copilot with items listed and another screenshot of one of the items listed opened in the app](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/app-copilot-find-item-open-item-1024x551.png)  
Continue by asking questions about a report listed in app Copilot. Or click on a report, staying within the app experience with report-scoped Copilot in apps available for more questions and insights based on the report in view.  
![Screenshot of a report in an app with report-scoped Copilot expanded with a question-and-answer response.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/report-copilot-in-app-question-response-1024x604.png)

main_title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
title: App authors have control over app-scoped Copilot
content:
## App authors have control over app-scoped Copilot  
App authors, you have control over app Copilot shown in your app navigation. If Copilot is enabled in your tenant, app Copilot (Preview) is default on in workspace apps. App Copilot is not yet available in org apps (Preview). But you can control visibility of app Copilot in your workspace apps from *Update app > Setup > Advanced Settings > Show Copilot in app navigation*.  
For more info, get an [overview on Copilot for Power BI](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/copilot-introduction) and [how to enable Copilot in Power BI](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/copilot-enable-power-bi), including licensing details.

main_title: Power BI app Copilot: AI scoped to the curated content in an app (Preview)
title: We’d love to hear your feedback as we work on what’s next
content:
## We’d love to hear your feedback as we work on what’s next  
Like seen during a sneak peek at the Fabric Community Conference in Europe, we’re working on more for app Copilot – from a more conversational experience without the need to pick an item every time you ask a question to the ability to get an overview of the reporting in an app. But just like all app improvements and Copilot improvements to date, we depend on your feedback.  
As you use app Copilot, use the thumbs up and thumbs down emojis on responses and let us know what you think. Or comment on this article and [post ideas](https://ideas.fabric.microsoft.com/) to the Fabric community.

main_title: Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users
title: Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users
content:
# Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users  
![Headshot of article author Denyse Niwenshuti](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b7cf8ff7eba58f76399e5834eca3e3d31f7d7060b7e52d04f5f01eac5204a2f3?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Denyse Niwenshuti](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/dniwenshuti/ "Posts by Denyse Niwenshuti")**  
October 28, 2025

main_title: Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users
title: What’s Changing?
content:
## What’s Changing?  
Microsoft has [announced](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/officeeos/announcing-the-retirement-for-office-online-server/4462402) that Office Online Server (OOS) will be retired effective **December 31, 2026**. As a result, PBIRS users will no longer be able to [host Excel workbooks](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/report-server/excel-oos) in PBIRS using OOS after **November 2026**, in accordance with the [PBIRS Support Timelines Policy](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/report-server/support-timeline). Additionally, beginning with the **January 2026 PBIRS release**, configuration of PBIRS to use OOS for hosting Excel workbooks will no longer be supported.

main_title: Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users
title: What Does This Mean for You?
content:
## What Does This Mean for You?  
* **January 2026:** PBIRS will remove the option to host Excel workbooks using OOS.
* **November 2026:** Support for hosting Excel workbooks via OOS in PBIRS ends.
* **December 31, 2026:** Official end of support for OOS.

main_title: Deprecation Announcement: Office Online Server Retirement and What it Means for Power BI Report Server Users
title: **Next Steps**
content:
## **Next Steps**  
* **Switch to Microsoft 365 Excel:** Use Excel for viewing workbooks.
* **Move to Power BI Service:** For a cloud-first experience, migrate your reports and workbooks to the Power BI service.  
If you currently use OOS to host Excel workbooks in PBIRS, your reports will keep working until November 2026. To prevent any disruptions, it’s important for customers to plan ahead and move to the recommended alternatives before that deadline.

main_title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
content:
# Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)  
![Headshot of article author Maya Shenhav](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3b2ecd87cf86c7dcc40b5fe33f2e4414b06c41185910450cdae44370f6a52a8c?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Maya Shenhav](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/mshenhav/ "Posts by Maya Shenhav")**
Power BI Mobile and Storytelling  
October 27, 2025  
This feature was developed in direct response to feedback from our user community and is designed to provide an efficient tool for managing multiple Power BI add-ins within PowerPoint presentations.

main_title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
title: Background
content:
## Background  
Power BI Storytelling enables users to embed interactive reports and visuals into PowerPoint, supporting data-driven presentations across organizations. As adoption has grown, many of you expressed the need for a centralized mechanism to manage and update several Power BI add-ins across multiple slides. You told us that you are using Power BI add-in for PowerPoint to create data-centric presentations, which you are updating every week or month, and that going over all the add-ins in the presentation and repeating the same operation is time consuming. The Power BI Controller addresses this need by allowing users to execute bulk operations from a single interface.

main_title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
title: An example scenario
content:
## An example scenario  
Consider a business leader preparing a monthly review presentation containing multiple embedded Power BI reports covering sales, operations, and finance. This user creates a new version of the presentation every month, with that month latest data captured as image mode, and then shares it with the relevant stakeholders.  
Capabilities with Power BI Controller:  
* Switch all add-ins to from their current image view to live view with a single action, ensuring every report displays the most current data.
* After updating, revert all add-ins to image view, locking the data for secure sharing.
* Distribute the finalized presentation to stakeholders, confident that all information is accurate and up to date, without the need for repetitive manual updates.

main_title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
title: Introducing the Power BI Controller add-in
content:
## Introducing the Power BI Controller add-in  
The Power BI Controller is a task pane add-in that serves as a central command center for all Power BI add-ins within a presentation. With this tool, users can efficiently perform operations across all add-ins, ensuring consistency and saving valuable time.  
To get this add-in go to ‘Add-ins’ in PowerPoint ribbon and search for ‘Microsoft Power BI Controller’. Select ‘Add’ to add-in to your ribbon. Once you select it, a new panel will open with the commands that the Power BI Controller supports in this preview release (change view modes from snapshot/public snapshot to live and vice versa, and sync with Power BI. More commands will be added soon.)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/controller_blog-1.gif)  
When you apply a command on the entire presentation, only the add-ins that can honor the command will execute it. Other add-ins might reject it and will report back to the controller as not applicable. For example, if you send a ‘Switch to snapshot’ command and there are add-ins in the presentation that are already in snapshot mode they will not re-take the snapshot but will report to the controller that this command is not applicable for them. Other add-ins, which are in live mode, will respect the command and will switch to snapshot mode.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/status-1024x576.png)

main_title: Introducing Power BI Controller: Streamlining Storytelling with Bulk Operations (Preview)
title: **Call to Action**
content:
### **Call to Action**  
We encourage all Power BI Storytelling users to leverage the Power BI Controller in their next presentation.  
Your feedback is invaluable and will help us continue to enhance this feature. Please share your experiences and suggestions and keep voting on[Ideas](https://ideas.powerbi.com/)to help us determine what to build next.

main_title: Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI
title: Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI
content:
# Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI  
![Headshot of article author Ben Zulauf](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c2f37d548e85732ff17934fabe1079f80072d26e9ce0f645bc272f7aac740c88?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Ben Zulauf](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/bezulaumicrosoft-com/ "Posts by Ben Zulauf")**  
October 20, 2025  
We’ve upgraded the Report Copilot experience in Power BI, making it easier than ever to create, edit, and refine beautiful, data-rich reports with the help of AI.  
With this update, Copilot in Power BI not only helps you create entire report pages in seconds but now also gives you more control, flexibility, and visual intelligence than ever before. The new Report Copilot experience is available now in the Power BI service and will be coming to Power BI Desktop in November 2025.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Create_page_v3-1-1024x485.png)

main_title: Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI
title: **Smarter, More Capable Visual Creation**
content:
### **Smarter, More Capable Visual Creation**  
The new Copilot understands your data and intent more deeply than ever. Just tell it what you want to create, and watch your ideas come to life instantly.  
* **Better visual recommendations:** Copilot now selects the most appropriate visuals for your data automatically.
* **Expanded visual library:** Copilot supports a wider range of visuals, giving you more options to present insights exactly how you envision them.
* **Improved context awareness:** When you describe what you want to see, Copilot now understands more nuanced instructions, producing more accurate and insightful results.

main_title: Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI
title: **Do More with Existing Reports**
content:
### **Do More with Existing Reports**  
You asked and we listened—the updated Report Copilot goes beyond creating new reports. Now you can collaborate with Copilot as you iterate, instead of starting from scratch every time.  
* Add visuals to existing report pages.
* Change or replace visuals to refine how insights are displayed.
* Delete visuals that are no longer needed.
* Works with the undo and redo stack, so you can confidently experiment and make changes.

main_title: Introducing Improvements to the Report Copilot in Power BI
title: **Getting Started: Accessing Report Copilot**
content:
### **Getting Started: Accessing Report Copilot**  
To access the new Copilot experience:  
1. Open a report in the Power BI service.
2. Select ‘Edit’ to enter edit mode.
3. Once in editing, you’ll see the ‘Copilot’ button in the ribbon.
4. From there, you can start creating, modifying, or refining visuals directly within your existing report.  
> Tip: If you don’t see the Copilot button, make sure you’re working in a Copilot-enabled workspace, one assigned to Fabric or Premium (P1+) capacity, and that your admin has enabled Copilot in Microsoft Fabric.
>
> ### **Creating with Copilot Just Got Better**
>
> With the new Report Copilot, building reports in Power BI is faster, smarter, and more intuitive than ever. From richer visuals to more flexible editing and undo/redo support, everything works together to make creating with Copilot a smoother and more powerful experience.
>
> To learn more, refer to [Create reports in the Power BI service with Copilot – Power BI](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/copilot-create-report-service).

main_title: Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models
title: Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models
content:
# Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models  
![Headshot of article author Kay Unkroth](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b5b57054b0358727ef517293fa7221f3d8143d498c86a60df7feefbf7d98f2ea?s=62&d=mm&r=g)  
**[Kay Unkroth](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/author/kayu/ "Posts by Kay Unkroth")**
Principal Program Manager  
October 16, 2025  
With exponential growth in data volumes and complexity, Power BI customers demand enterprise BI solutions that scale to petabytes, are secure, easy to manage, and accessible to all users across their organizations. Such solutions require extensive API surface area for enterprise management scenarios. For example, you can use the [Fabric item CRUD APIs](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/articles/item-management/item-management-overview) to list semantic models, create and update them, and copy them to other workspaces. You can also use the Power BI REST APIs to perform [advanced refresh operations](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/power-bi/datasets/refresh-dataset-in-group) and [execute DAX queries](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/power-bi/datasets/execute-queries-in-group), among other things. For semantic model metadata operations and refreshes, you can also leverage XMLA endpoints and the Tabular Object Model (TOM) through [Analysis Services client libraries](https://learn.microsoft.com/analysis-services/client-libraries?view=sql-analysis-services-2025).  
We are releasing a new Fabric REST API for configuring connection bindings for semantic models. A connection binding defines what data connection a semantic model will use to connect to an underlying data source. In scenarios where data sources change—such as moving from development to production environments, migrating infrastructure, or switching connection details—being able to programmatically update these bindings is crucial. The new [Bind Semantic Model Connection REST API](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2329807) marks a significant improvement for BI pros and developers to automate these tasks.

main_title: Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models
title: Bind Connection versus Bind to Gateway
content:
## Bind Connection versus Bind to Gateway  
The new [Bind Semantic Model Connection REST API](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2329807) supersedes the existing [Datasets – Bind to Gateway in Group](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/power-bi/datasets/bind-to-gateway-in-group) REST API in Power BI. It provides support for all connectivity types, including gateway connections, cloud connections, and default connection settings. It is also possible to unbind a semantic model thus leaving the semantic model in a disconnected state. Moreover, it is fully aligned with the [List Connections](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/core/connections/list-connections) and [List Item Connections](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/core/items/list-item-connections) REST APIs so that you can work seamlessly across multiple APIs to generate a connections request.

main_title: Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models
title: How to configure a connection binding
content:
## How to configure a connection binding  
Here’s a quick rundown of the typical steps to configure a connection binding:  
|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  | **Task** | **Comments** |
| Step 1 | List the existing connections for a semantic model | Use the [List Item Connections](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/core/items/list-item-connections) REST API. It returns one or multiple item connections, which correspond to the data sources the semantic model uses. |
| Step 2 | List all connections you can access | Use the [List Connections](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/core/connections/list-connections) REST API. It returns the connection details for all the connections you have access to. |
| Step 3 | Pick the data connection you want to use for the semantic model binding | Find the connection in the list connection response of Step 2 that matches the connection details of the item connection of Step 1. Take note of the connection id because you most likely will need it in subsequent steps.  If there is no matching connection, you can create one by using the [Create Connection](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/fabric/core/connections/create-connection) REST API. |
| Step 4 | Generate the payload for the Bind Semantic Model Connection request | Create a JSON document with the connection bindingdetails, which typically include the connectivityType, the connectionDetails, and the object id of the connection you want to bind.  Note that the connection id is not applicable if you want to use default connection settings (“connectivityType”: “Automatic”) or if you want to unbind a data source (“connectivityType”: “None”). |
| Step 5 | Submit the JSON payload in a POST request to the [Bind Semantic Model Connection](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2329807) REST API | You must submit a request for each data source individually. To bind multiple data source references of a semantic model, you must submit multiple bind connection requests. |

main_title: Announcing a new Fabric REST API for connection binding of semantic models
title: We’d love to hear from you
content:
## We’d love to hear from you  
The new [Bind Semantic Model Connection REST API](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2329807) transforms the connection binding process through seamless automation. Visit the official Fabric REST API documentation as a detailed API reference and use the REST API Try It feature for an intuitive and interactive quick start. We hope that this new REST API for configuring connection bindings lets you streamline your semantic model lifecycle management, deployment automation, and administrative scripts with greater ease and consistency than previously possible.  
We value the feedback of our community and are eager to hear your experiences with the new API. Please connect with us on our forums, submit suggestions, or report issues through the official Power BI support channels. Your input will help us shape future enhancements and ensure our APIs meet the diverse needs of our BI pros, partners, and users.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Bing Map deprecation plan & Update in Power BI
content:
## General  
### Bing Map deprecation plan & Update in Power BI  
To ensure a seamless experience and stay ahead of upcoming Microsoft’s plan to retire Bing Maps for Enterprise, Power BI is proactively transitioning from Bing Maps to Azure Maps. By making this change early, Power BI users will benefit from enhanced mapping capabilities and long-term support. We encourage customers to begin updating their reports to Azure Maps visuals to stay future ready.  
**Power BI Desktop and Web (Edit- mode)**  
Earlier, we shared plans to remove the Bing Maps icon from the Visualization pane. After reconsideration, we’ve decided to keep the icon visible for now to ensure continuity and minimize disruption.  
Please note that the Bing Maps visual is still slated for deprecation, and we’re currently discussing the timeline. Any existing Bing Maps already in your reports will still be available.  
In preparation for the upcoming change, upgrade to Azure Maps unless:  
* You have team members who would consume the report in China, Korea, or government clouds.
* You’re physically located in China or Korea (regardless of where your home tenant is located).
* You’re part of a government cloud.  
We’re working to support Azure Maps in these unsupported regions. If you and all report users are in a supported region, you’re encouraged to start using Azure Maps now.  
Learn how to [upgrade to Azure Maps](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/azure-maps/power-bi-visual-conversion). To see the list of supported regions, see [Azure Maps service geographic scope](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/azure-maps/geographic-scope). For more information about Azure Maps, see [Get started with Azure Maps Power BI visual](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/azure-maps/power-bi-visual-get-started).  
**Power BI Report Builder**  
The migration of paginated reports map visuals from Bing Maps to Azure Maps has begun. This migration will occur in two phases: first, migrating to Azure Maps in PBIRB, followed by migration to Azure Maps for paginated reports in the service. The initial phase is complete. Beginning with the September release of PBIRB, users can create map visuals powered by Azure Maps by default. However, paginated reports published in the service will continue to use Bing Maps until phase two is completed. Phase two is expected to be completed by mid-November.  
Paginated reports authors can revert to Bing Maps for authoring in PBIRB until both phases are complete. To enable this, users must set the ‘RevertToBingMaps’ registry key located in the ‘Computer\HKEY\_LOCAL\_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Microsoft Power BI Report Builder’ folder to 1. If the ‘Microsoft Power BI Report Builder’ folder does not exist, it should be manually created before setting the registry key.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Copilot to write DAX queries in DAX query view (Generally Available)
content:
## Copilot and AI  
### Copilot to write DAX queries in DAX query view (Generally Available)  
This innovative capability empowers users to leverage Copilot assistance directly within both the web and Desktop Power BI experiences, making DAX query creation easier and more efficient than ever before.  
Getting started is simple. In Power BI Desktop or Power BI web modeling, open the DAX query view and select the Copilot button. Describe the insights you are seeking, and Copilot generates the corresponding DAX query. Conversationally edit the DAX query with Copilot, run it as you go, and keep it when you are ready.  
The following screenshot shows Copilot helping to write a DAX query from the prompt ‘How are we tracking towards our targeted deliveries for each month?’ in DAX query view of Power BI Desktop. The DAX query results show by month the number of deliveries made, the target, attainment %, and variance to target.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-1.png)  
The next screenshot demonstrates how to write a DAX query to answer the user prompt ‘Can you indicate which month we were over target or under target on deliveries?’ in DAX query view of Power BI web modeling. The DAX query results show by month the number of deliveries made, the target, variance to target, and the status of each month as over or under target.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-2.png)  
Copilot is grounded in the semantic model, and AI instructions set on the model by Prep for AI. This includes verified answers by understanding the fields used and filters applied. Semantic model tables, columns, descriptions, display folders, hierarchy information, relationships, and measures are all known already to Copilot when creating DAX queries.  
Copilot to help write DAX queries is used in DAX query view, and in chat with your data experiences when a DAX query is returned as well as data agents when a semantic model is included.  
To learn more, refer to the [Write DAX queries with Copilot](https://learn.microsoft.com/dax/dax-copilot) documentation, and try it out today!

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Button slicer (Generally Available)
content:
## Reporting  
### Button slicer (Generally Available)  
Along with this release, we’ve added a few exciting enhancements to make your experience even better, including Cross-highlighting, Auto grid, and more.  
**Cross-highlighting**  
Like the Chiclet slicer, the Button Slicer now supports cross-highlighting to help you uncover deeper insights. This means the slicer can interact dynamically with other visuals on your report page by emphasizing relevant values and dimming unrelated ones.  
For example: If you select North America in a column chart, the Button Slicer will:  
* Highlight buttons like Canada and United States (since they belong to North America).
* Dim all other countries to indicate they are outside the selection but keep them visible.  
To use this feature, simply drag a field into this new field, well called ‘Highlight label’ in the Build visual pane.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-3.png)  
You can now start interacting with now by simply selecting a value on a visual. For example, in the below example if you click on District L1-04 in the scatter chart, you will see the DM of the district L1-04 highlighted while other values are dimmed in the button slicer.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-4.png)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-5.png)  
**Auto grid**  
With the new Auto grid option turned on, your slicer layout becomes smarter. When enabled (and it is by default), the arrangement of rows and columns automatically adjusts based on a defined maximum limit, ensuring a clean and responsive design without manual effort.  
For example, following is the screenshot with Rows set to 5 and Columns set to 3 and **Auto grid on**:  
**Auto grid**  
With the new Auto grid option turned on, your slicer layout becomes smarter. When enabled (and it is by default), the arrangement of rows and columns automatically adjusts based on a defined maximum limit, ensuring a clean and responsive design without manual effort.  
For example, following is the screenshot with Rows set to 5 and Columns set to 3 and **Auto grid on**:  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-6.png)  
Following is the screenshot with **Auto grid Off**:  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-7.png)  
In addition to these updates, we’ve introduced several accessibility improvements to make Button Slicer more user-friendly and inclusive.  
To learn more about these enhancements and how to use them effectively, refer to the [Create a button slicer (preview)](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/visuals/power-bi-visualization-button-slicer) documentation.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Visual calculations are now supported in embed for your customers (Preview)
content:
### Visual calculations are now supported in embed for your customers (Preview)  
Visual calculations are now supported in [Power BI Embedded—specifically in the Embed for your customers scenario](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/guidance/powerbi-implementation-planning-usage-scenario-embed-for-your-customers). This powerful enhancement brings even more flexibility and intelligence to your embedded analytics solutions.  
With visual calculations, users, developers and ISVs can now define custom calculations directly within visuals, without needing to modify the underlying data model or write complex DAX. This means faster iteration, more dynamic insights, and a smoother experience for end users. You can also hide/unhide fields on visual and set [visual-level format strings](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-custom-format-strings#add-a-visual-level-format-string).

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Automatically expand table columns to fill available space
content:
### Automatically expand table columns to fill available space  
We’ve added a new option to table formatting that makes your visuals look cleaner and more balanced—automatically. With ‘Grow to fit’, any extra space in the visual is evenly distributed across existing columns when the total column width is smaller than the visual container. No more manual resizing to fill the gap.  
If your table isn’t using the full visual width, you can manually resize columns or use Auto-size width, but now there’s an improved solution. For example, this table doesn’t fully utilize the available space:  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-8.png)  
Navigate to the format pane under Column headers > Options, toggle Auto-size width to ‘On’, and set ‘Resize behavior’ to ‘Grow to fit’. Instantly, your table expands to make full use of the available space.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-9.png)  
The additional available space will be distributed across the columns:  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-10.png)  
It’s a subtle upgrade that makes your data layouts cleaner, more balanced, and easier to read. Note that this will not interfere with any adjustments you make to column widths: once a column width is manually adjusted, it won’t be automatically expanded.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Introducing the new Power BI Controller in Power BI in PowerPoint (Preview)
content:
### Introducing the new Power BI Controller in Power BI in PowerPoint (Preview)  
This feature was developed in direct response to feedback from our user community and is designed to provide an efficient tool for managing multiple Power BI add-ins within PowerPoint presentations.  
Users can embed interactive reports and visuals into PowerPoint, supporting data-driven presentations across organizations. As adoption has grown, many of you expressed the need for a centralized mechanism to manage and update several Power BI add-ins across multiple slides. You told us that you are using Power BI add-in for PowerPoint to create data-centric presentations, which you are updating every week or month, and that going over all the add-ins in the presentation and repeating the same operation is time consuming. The Power BI Controller addresses this need by allowing users to execute bulk operations from a single interface.  
The Power BI Controller is a task pane add-in that serves as a central command center for all Power BI add-ins within a presentation.  
To get this add-in go to ‘Add-ins’ in PowerPoint ribbon and search for ‘Microsoft Power BI Controller’. Select ‘Add’ to add-in to your ribbon. Once you select it, a new panel will open with the list of commands that you can apply. Pick the command you wish to run and click ‘Apply’. This will trigger the discovery phase in which the controller will look for all Power BI content in the presentation and next the selected command will be executed on the discovered Power BI add-ins.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-11.png)  
To learn more, refer to [View and Present live Power BI Data in PowerPoint](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/collaborate-share/service-power-bi-powerpoint-add-in-view-present#add-in-side-pane).

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Performance analyzer in web to see the load times of visuals
content:
### Performance analyzer in web to see the load times of visuals  
In September, we announced the availability of a performance analyzer pane on the web to see the load times of the visuals in your report where your users are going to be viewing it. Unfortunately, the rollout was delayed.  
This functionality will be available to your tenant in the next few weeks.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-12.png)  
To learn more about this new capability while editing a report in web, refer to the [Use Performance Analyzer to examine report performance](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/performance-analyzer) documentation.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Export Query Results (Preview)
content:
## Data connectivity  
### Export Query Results (Preview)  
Export Query Results in Power BI Desktop unlocks seamless data portability and collaboration across Microsoft Fabric. This feature empowers analysts to take transformed, cleaned data from Power Query and export it directly to trusted destinations – such as Dataflows Gen2, Lakehouses, and other cloud stores – without relying on complex workarounds or third-party tools. By meeting users where they work (Power BI Desktop) it reduces duplication of effort, accelerates data sharing, and drives interoperability across Fabric workloads.  
To enable this feature, select the Preview feature settings in Power BI Desktop.  
Users can select export query results from the PQ ribbon,  
![A screenshot of a computer  
AI-generated content may be incorrect.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/a-screenshot-of-a-computer-ai-generated-content-m.png)  
Select an online destination, ![A screenshot of a computer  
AI-generated content may be incorrect.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/a-screenshot-of-a-computer-ai-generated-content-m-1.png)  
And export their queries to this destination, where they can choose to modify the Dataflow.
![A screenshot of a computer  
AI-generated content may be incorrect.](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/a-screenshot-of-a-computer-ai-generated-content-m-2.png)  
The result is improved data gravity in OneLake, streamlined refresh and monitoring capabilities, and a minimal-click experience that supports both new and existing destinations. Ultimately, this feature bridges the gap between desktop analytics and enterprise-scale data integration, enabling organizations to maximize the value of their data investments.  
To learn more about how to use this feature: [Export Query Results in Power BI Desktop | Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/power-bi/transform-model/export-query-results).

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Power BI Desktop is now supported on ARM
content:
## Other  
### Power BI Desktop is now supported on ARM  
Power BI Desktop is now supported on Windows on ARM PCs that have the 2025-09 Cumulative Update installed ([KB5065789](https://support.microsoft.com/topic/september-29-2025-kb5065789-os-builds-26200-6725-and-26100-6725-preview-fa03ce47-cec5-4d1c-87d0-cac4195b4b4e)). Adding ARM support to Power BI Desktop brings powerful data analytics capabilities to a broader range of hardware—unlocking faster performance, improved battery life, and seamless experiences on modern, energy-efficient devices.  
Why ARM? As more users adopt ARM-powered laptops and tablets for their portability and efficiency, it’s essential that Power BI keeps pace. ARM support ensures smoother operation, better resource utilization, and a future-ready foundation for data professionals working across diverse environments.  
Whether you’re building dashboards on the go or analyzing data from anywhere, Power BI Desktop on ARM makes it easier than ever.

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Sankey Chart by Powerviz
content:
## Visualizations  
### Sankey Chart by Powerviz  
The Powerviz [Sankey Chart](https://appsource.microsoft.com/en-us/product/power-bi-visuals/truvizinc1674781244292.sankey-chart-by-powerviz?tab=Overview) is a dynamic flow diagram that visualizes the proportional movement of data, resources, or processes across categories or stages. With weighted connections and flexible layouts, it helps users uncover insights within complex systems.  
**Key Features**  
* Chart Orientation: Switch seamlessly between vertical and horizontal orientation.
* Node Customizations: Control node appearance, spacing, visibility, and interactions for optimal clarity.
* Multi-Level Support: Add multiple levels to visualize layered, hierarchical flows.
* Data Colors: Access 30+ color palettes, including colour-blind-safe options.
* Fill Patterns: Highlight nodes with patterns or upload your own.
* Conditional Formatting: Highlight outliers with based on measures or categories rules.
* Smart Labels: Display data and header labels for enhanced readability.
* Hide Null Nodes: Instantly remove nodes with null or blank data.
* Image Labels: Add image URLs to show visuals inside or outside the nodes.
* Import/Export: Save and reuse themes easily.
* Templates: Use built-in templates or design your own.  
Other features included are Sorting, Ranking, Show Condition, Grid View and more.  
**Business Use Cases**  
Customer Journey Mapping, Expense Breakdown, Supply Chain Flow.  
* Try Sankey Chart visual for FREE from [AppSource](https://appsource.microsoft.com/en-us/product/power-bi-visuals/truvizinc1674781244292.sankey-chart-by-powerviz?tab=Overview)
* Check out all features of the visual: [Demo\_file](https://app.powerbi.com/view?r=eyJrIjoiZTgyMGYwYzItZGExMi00MGUyLWIzODYtY2VlNmM3MmUwYWE0IiwidCI6ImNhODc1ZjVhLTcwNmMtNDFmNS04YTczLWNlMTQ0ZjMxMDhlMyIsImMiOjF9)
* Step-by-step instructions: [Documentation](https://docs.powerviz.ai/powerviz/sankey-chart/introduction)
* YouTube Video: [Video\_Link](https://youtu.be/YHxMy0uP5Ac?si=exl2vBfZNAawSmkg)
* Learn more about visuals: <https://powerviz.ai/>
* Follow Powerviz: <https://lnkd.in/gN_9Sa6U>  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-16.png)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-17.png)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Your Timeline Slicer: Reimagining Date Filtering for Modern Dashboards
content:
### Your Timeline Slicer: Reimagining Date Filtering for Modern Dashboards  
**What problem are we solving?**  
Dashboard real estate is precious, but traditional timeline slicers often consume too much space while lacking the flexibility today’s data professionals need. After experiencing firsthand the limitations and occasional bugs of existing solutions, we built Your Timeline Slicer from the ground up to deliver what the Power BI community has been asking for.  
**Why Your Timeline Slicer changes the game**  
Our visual combines the familiar timeline functionality you know with breakthrough space-saving design – reclaiming up to 60% more dashboard space through ultra-compact mode. Beyond size, we have intelligent features that make reporting effortless: dynamic **‘Current Period’ and ‘Latest Available’** filtering that automatically focuses on what matters most, extensive customization options to match any brand or style, and rock-solid performance. Whether you’re building executive summaries, financial dashboards, or mobile-first reports, Your Timeline Slicer adapts to your workflow – not the other way around.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-18.png)  
Ready to experience the difference? Download Your Timeline Slicer from [AppSource](https://appsource.microsoft.com/en-us/product/power-bi-visuals/based-on.based_on_your_timeline) and discover how smart date filtering can transform your dashboards. [Based On Website](https://bit.ly/4g1akDv)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Drill Down Scatter PRO by ZoomCharts
content:
### Drill Down Scatter PRO by ZoomCharts  
What if exploring complex data was as easy as scrolling a smartphone app? You could make smarter and more interactive reports that allow more people (managers, C-suite, and other stakeholders) to take part in data analysis themselves and quickly find the insights they need for data-driven decisions. When designing our Drill Down Scatter PRO, we focused on three things:  
* **Incredible user experience:** Freeform panning. Click to drill down. Scroll or pinch to zoom in. Multiple ways to select data. Scatter PRO makes it easy for anyone to navigate even the most complex data.
* **On-chart Drill Down:** Have hundreds or even thousands of markers? No problem – you can simplify your chart by using multiple category fields and combine smaller data points into large markers. Simply click on it to drill down and see more detailed insights on-demand.
* **Customization:** Scatter PRO offers all the necessary tools to create the perfect scatter plot for your report. Regression lines, marker, label, legend customization, tooltip content fields, reference lines and areas, and even shaded areas at your selected coordinates! [Read more in our blog article](https://zoomcharts.com/en/microsoft-power-bi-custom-visuals/blog/how-to-guide-drill-down-scatter-pro-for-power-bi?utm_source=microsoftcom&utm_medium=ms_blog&utm_campaign=feature_summary_october_2025).
* [**Get Drill Down Scatter PRO**](https://zoomcharts.com/en/goto/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fappsource.microsoft.com%2Fen-gb%2Fproduct%2Fpower-bi-visuals%2F32204330.drilldownscatterprobyzoomcharts%2F&utm_source=microsoftcom&utm_medium=ms_blog&utm_campaign=feature_summary_october_2025)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-19.png)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Multiple Sparklines
content:
### Multiple Sparklines  
With the Multiple Sparklines visual, you can design an Income Statement that is both insightful and visually compelling.  
* 1st column displays Profit and Loss as a waterfall chart.
* 2nd column shows each item as a percentage of Revenue (common-size analysis).
* The 3rd column presents the past five-year trend.
* 4th column compares each item with the previous year.
* The 5th column benchmarks result against two major competitors.  
For a step-by-step tutorial on how to create this type of Income Statement, visit:
[Income Statement in Power BI](https://www.excelnaccess.com/income-statement-in-power-bi/)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-21.png)  
Following is another example of an Income Statement  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-22.png)  
Download this visual from [APPSOURCE](https://appsource.microsoft.com/en-us/product/power-bi-visuals/WA200002816?tab=Overview)  
For more information visit <https://www.excelnaccess.com/sparklines/>  
or contact [zubair@excelnaccess.com](mailto:zubair@excelnaccess.com)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Performance Bar by JTA
content:
### Performance Bar by JTA  
Take your Power BI dashboards to the next level with the Performance Bar by JTA, a clean visual for tracking progress and status briefly. Categories are displayed as streamlined horizontal bars with an optional markers and value label, making comparisons effortless. With simple customization to match your theme – and an optional total bar – it delivers a clear, modern way to tell your performance story.  
**Key Features**  
* **Bar customization:** Configure bar height, colors, borders, and background to match your report theme.
* **Flexible labelling:** Show or hide individual labels and choose their position for clear, uncluttered reading.
* **Adjustable scale:** Change the scale to emphasize what matters most.
* **Marker styling:** Personalize circle markers (size, color, border) for highlights and targets.
* **Marker styling:** Personalize circle markers (size, color, border) for highlights and targets.
* **Total Bar:** Optionally display a summary bar for an at-a-glance overall view.
* **Configurable tooltips:** Define exactly which fields appear and where tooltips show up.
* **Subtle animation:** Bring bars to life with a clean growth animation.  
**Resources**  
Explore more [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q_r3Zsj-ekQ). Also, if you want to download it, you can find the visual package on the [AppSource](https://appsource.microsoft.com/en-us/product/power-bi-visuals/jtathedatascientists1592432854663.performance_bar?tab=Overview).  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-23.png)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-24.png)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: Financial Reporting Matrix v8.2
content:
### Financial Reporting Matrix v8.2  
**More control, customization, and clarity**  
The Financial Reporting Matrix just got even better! With version 8.2.0.0, we’ve introduced powerful new features, expanded customization options, and refined the user experience to give report creators unprecedented control over their layouts, formatting, and interactivity.  
**New in v8.2**  
* [RowHeaderParent() function](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Table-functions) – Reference parent rows in calculations and formatting.
* [Invert Sign Factor](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Invert-sign-factor) – Quickly reverse value signs for reporting preferences.
* [Row options in Conditional Formatting](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Conditional-formatting#using-row-options-as-conditions) – make rules based on Inverted sign, allow drilling, and more.
* [Comments everywhere](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Commenting#formatting-and-export-to-excel) – Add and format comments on row and column headers, and export to Excel with comments.
* [Custom expansion icons](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Show---hide-expansion-icons#change-icon-shape) – Change shape, color, size, and indentation.
* [Pin Columns](https://github.com/Profitbase/PowerBI-visuals-FinancialReportingMatrix/wiki/Pin-columns) – Keep important columns visible when scrolling.  
**Improvements**  
* Column header names showing in stepped layout.
* Hide empty rows with rendered measures in rows.
* JSON-based row options recognition.
* Smoother horizontal scroll for formula editing.
* Row subtotals fix for ‘In rows’ measure placement.
* Rename your Applied Steps.
* Change column expansion icon size.  
[Get the latest version from AppSource](https://appsource.microsoft.com/product/power-bi-visuals/WA200000642?tab=Overview)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-25.png)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-26.png)

main_title: Power BI October 2025 Feature Summary
title: BI Pixie by DataChant – Measure the Effectiveness of Your BI Assets in 6 Dimensions from Adoption to Security
content:
### BI Pixie by DataChant – Measure the Effectiveness of Your BI Assets in 6 Dimensions from Adoption to Security  
Since its launch 2024, [BI Pixie](https://bipixie.com/) has evolved from its initial adoption and engagement measurement offering an all-encompassing intelligence suite for organizations that want to maximize their return on investment in Power BI. BI Pixie now offers insights in six key dimensions: Adoption, Engagement, User Satisfaction, Business Outcome, Performance and Security. Here are the recent updates and new capabilities in BI Pixie.  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-27.png)  
![](https://powerbiblogsfd-ep-aveghkfaexa3e4bx.b02.azurefd.net//wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-31333-28.png)  
With its unique instrumentation technology, BI Pixie captures detailed auditing information, providing a comprehensive view of your BI audience and analytic assets. Designed to ensure your data stays in your organization and scale to tens of thousands of reports and users, BI Pixie can be deployed in your Azure tenant or Power Platform environment in minutes.  
Leverage the capabilities of BI Pixie to drive user adoption, reduce attrition, boost your data governance and optimize the impact of your BI initiatives with our unprecedented auditing and real-time detection of data leaks due to faulty implementations of Row-Level Security (RLS).  
Discover more by exploring [BI Pixie Dashboard](https://appsource.microsoft.com/product/power-bi/datachant-5311696.bi-pixie-app-enterprise?tab=Overview) on Microsoft AppSource, and [reach out](https://bipixie.com/start-a-trial/) for a free subscription.

main_title: Power BI Report Server September 2025 Feature Summary
title: General announcements
content:
## General announcements  
**SQL Server 2025 Updates**  
Starting with SQL Server 2025, Microsoft is consolidating all on-premises reporting services under Power BI Report Server (PBIRS). No new versions of SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS) will be released. PBIRS becomes the default on-premises reporting solution for SQL Server.  
You can expect more information about specific editions when SQL Server 2025 is in General Availability (GA). The [Reporting Services consolidation FAQ](https://learn.microsoft.com/sql/reporting-services/reporting-services-consolidation-faq?view=sql-server-ver17) documentation outlines the implications of these changes for you as a customer and addresses any questions you might have.  
**32-bit Version Deprecation**  
In alignment with Power BI Desktop for service, PBI Desktop for RS will only support 64-bit builds starting with this PBIRS September release.
